68564.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence SN47.40, it appears as part of the Satipaṭṭhānasaṃyutta, indicating it is a sutta that analyzes the foundations of mindfulness. The compound is a kammadhāraya where vibhaṅga (analysis) qualifies sutta (discourse).

33400.meaning_1: Second Discourse on Śramaṇas and Brāhmaṇas
33400.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence SN14.38 confirms this is a title of a sutta within the Dhātusaṃyutta (Group of Elements), specifically the second of a series discussing Śramaṇas and Brāhmaṇas.

916.meaning_1: sutta about the naked ascetic Kassapa
916.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
Contextual sentence SN41.9 indicates this is a title within the cittasaṃyuttaṃ. The sutta involves a dialogue with the naked ascetic Kassapa.

39397.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
This is the title of SN12.27 within the Nidānasaṃyutta, specifically the seventh sutta. It discusses the twelve links of dependent origination (paṭiccasamuppāda) and the conditions (paccaya) that sustain the cycle of existence.

16240.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The lemma is a compound of upa (towards) + vāṇa (stem of vāṇī, meaning speech or word) + sutta (thread/sutta). Found in SN12.26 within the Nidānasaṃyutta. Meaning refers to a specific sutta about listening to or heeding teachings.

39393.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence (sn12.27), 'paccayasamudayaṃ' is used in the compound phrase 'paccayaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ paccayasamudayaṃ pajānāti' (understands dependency, its origin). The compound is a genitive compound (chaṭṭhī tappurisa) meaning 'the origin of the condition.'
39393.sutta_1: yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ paccayaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ paccayasamudayaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ paccayanirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ paccayanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti.
39393.example_1: When a noble disciple thus understands dependency, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,

39384.meaning_2: cessation of conditions; stoppage of dependencies
39384.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence (SN12.27), paccayanirodhaṃ is the accusative singular of this compound, referring specifically to the cessation of the twelve links of dependent origination (paṭiccasamuppāda). The compound structure is a genitive Tatpuruṣa, meaning "cessation of conditions."
39384.sutta_1: yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ paccayaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ paccayasamudayaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ paccayanirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ paccayanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti.
39384.example_1: When a noble disciple thus understands dependency, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,

39385.meaning_1: leading to the ending of the supporting condition
39385.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence, the word is in the masculine accusative singular form "paccayanirodhagāminiṃ", modifying "paṭipadaṃ" (path). It describes a practice that leads to the cessation of conditions (paccayanirodha).
39385.sutta_1: yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ paccayaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ paccayasamudayaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ paccayanirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ paccayanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti.
39385.example_1: When a noble disciple thus understands dependency, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,

49942.meaning_1: sutta about monks; discourse concerning monks
49942.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
Contextual sentence shows it as a title in the Nidānasaṃyutta. Compound of bhikkhu (monk) and sutta (discourse). While the literal meaning is "monk-sutta," in this context it refers to a specific discourse concerning monks. The term is part of the Saṃyutta Nikāya 12 collection (Nidānasaṃyutta).

20843.meaning_1: the chapter (vagga) of the Kāḷāras (a tribe or lineage)
20843.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence (sn12.40:3.9) states 'kaḷārakhattiyavaggo catuttho', identifying it as the fourth vagga (chapter/section) in a series, likely within the Saṃyutta Nikāya. It is a compound of 'kaḷāra' (likely meaning 'black' or referring to a specific lineage), 'khattiya' (warrior/noble), and 'vagga' (chapter/section).

50180.meaning_1: the sutta about what has come to be; the sutta on the actual
50180.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
This is a compound sutta title in the Nidānasaṃyutta of the Saṃyutta Nikāya. It belongs to a set of suttas defined in the family_set field.

45771.meaning_1: Way to the Far Shore; Way to the Beyond; last chapter of the Sutta Nipāta (SNP 56, KN5.56)
45771.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence (SN12.31), the word appears as "pārāyane" (locative singular of pārāyaṇa), referencing the "Pārāyaṇa" section of the Sutta Nipāta. The text quotes from the "Ajitapañha" within this chapter. This indicates the word functions as a title for a specific section of scripture, meaning "The Way to the Far Shore."
45771.example_1: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati. tatra kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ āmantesi, vuttamidaṃ, sāriputta, pārāyane [pārāyaṇe] ajitapañhe –

1191.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
Refers to a specific set of questions attributed to Ajita in the Sutta Nipāta, contextually used in a discourse setting.
1191.example_1: “Sāriputta, this was said in ‘The Way to the Far Shore’, in ‘The Questions of Ajita’:

20846.meaning_1: the Sutta on the Dye (or the Sutta on the Color)
20846.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The term appears in SN12.32 as the title of a sutta. According to commentaries, it refers to a dye vat (kaḷāra) used as a metaphor for the process of dependent origination. The compound is a kammadhāraya.

20842.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence, the monk is addressed as "kaḷārakhattiyo bhikkhu". The term is a compound of kaḷāra (crooked, protruding) and khattiya (warrior, noble), likely referring to his physical appearance or origin.
20842.sutta_1: atha kho kaḷārakhattiyo bhikkhu yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.
20842.example_1: Then the mendicant Kaḷāra the Aristocrat went up to Venerable Sāriputta and exchanged greetings with him.

10082.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
Formed from compound of assāsa (comfort, relief) + alattha (aorist of labhati, "to get"). In context, it indicates a lack of attainment of solace in the Dhamma training.
10082.sutta_1: “na hi nūna so āyasmā imasmiṃ dhammavinaye assāsamalatthā”ti.
10082.example_1: “That venerable mustn’t have gained any solace in this teaching and training.”

53884.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the context of SN 12.32, yaṃnidānā is the ablative singular (used adverbially) of the compound, meaning "from what source" or "due to what origin." The sentence structure shows a cause-and-effect relationship: knowing that the cessation of a specific cause (the source of rebirth) leads to the cessation of its effect (rebirth itself).
53884.sutta_1: ‘yaṃnidānā, āvuso, jāti, tassa nidānassa khayā khīṇasmiṃ khīṇāmhīti viditaṃ.
53884.example_1: ‘Reverends, when the source of rebirth ended, I knew “it is ended”.

28889.meaning_1: sutta about the facts of knowledge
28889.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
SN12.33 is identified in the nidānasaṃyuttaṃ as the ñāṇavatthusuttaṃ. The contextual sentence shows this as a title. The compound is a kammadhāraya (descriptive compound) where the sutta is about the vatthu (facts/base) of ñāṇa (knowledge).

28888.meaning_1: ground for knowledge; basis of knowledge
28888.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The compound ñāṇavatthu is formed from ñāṇa (knowledge) and vatthu (ground, basis, object). In the context of the sutta (SN 12.33), it refers to the foundational principles or conditions upon which knowledge of dependent origination (paṭiccasamuppāda) is established. The forty-four ñāṇavatthūni are specific analytical frameworks for understanding causality.
28888.example_1: “Mendicants, I will teach forty-four grounds for knowledge.

2414.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the context of SN12.33, the word is used as an indeclinable adverb in the instrumental case, modifying the participle pariyogāḷhena (understood through the context of the surrounding instrumental phrases). The meaning here is "through what is past and future" or "by means of what is past and future." It functions as a compound adverb modifying the action of knowing (ñāṇaṃ).
2414.example_1: yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ jarāmaraṇasamudayaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ jarāmaraṇanirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti, idamassa dhamme ñāṇaṃ. so iminā dhammena diṭṭhena viditena akālikena pattena pariyogāḷhena atītānāgatena yaṃ neti.

33251.meaning_1: Discourse on the Knowledge of the Second Truth
33251.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
This is the title of a sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN 12.34). It deals with the knowledge pertaining to the second noble truth (samudaya). The contextual sentence lists it as part of the Nidāna Saṃyutta.

57785.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence uses sattasattari as a numeral in agreement with ñāṇavatthūni (nt pl), indicating its function as a cardinal number meaning seventy-seven.
57785.example_1: “Mendicants, I will teach seventy-seven grounds for knowledge.

2411.grammar: ind, adv, acc sg of atīta
2411.meaning_1: regarding the past; about the past
2411.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence (sn12.34:2.4), atītaṃ functions as an indeclinable adverb meaning "regarding the past" or "in the past," modifying the knowledge (ñāṇaṃ) about the causal relationship between rebirth and aging/death. It is the accusative case form used adverbially.
2411.sutta_1: atītampi addhānaṃ jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇanti ñāṇaṃ, asati jātiyā natthi jarāmaraṇanti ñāṇaṃ;
2411.example_1: Also regarding the past: the knowledge that rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, and the knowledge that when rebirth doesn’t exist, there is no old age and death.

34709.meaning_1: knowledge of the stability of natural principles
34709.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The term is a compound meaning knowledge (ñāṇa) of the stability (ṭhiti) of dhammas (principles/phenomena). In the contextual sentence, it is described as being impermanent (khaya, vaya, virāga, nirodha), which is a key aspect of its meaning in Buddhist philosophy.
34709.sutta_1: yampissa taṃ dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇaṃ tampi khayadhammaṃ vayadhammaṃ virāgadhammaṃ nirodhadhammanti ñāṇaṃ.
34709.example_1: And also their knowledge that even this knowledge of the stability of natural principles is liable to end, vanish, fade away, and cease.

33152.meaning_1: the second discourse on ignorance as condition
33152.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
Context: SN12.36, a sutta in the Nidāna Saṃyutta. The compound signifies a discourse (sutta) concerning avijjā (ignorance) as a paccaya (condition), and it is the second (dutiya) such discourse.

35517.meaning_1: the sutta about not being swollen/puffed up
35517.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
Context indicates this is the title of a sutta in the Nidānasaṃyutta (SN 12.37). The meaning is derived from the negative prefix `na` and `tumha` (likely related to the root √tud or tuh, meaning to swell or be puffed up), referring to a state of not being inflated or arrogant. The compound is a kammadhāraya.

27038.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence shows the word is part of the Nidānasaṃyutta, specifically sutta 8 in that section. It likely discusses the role of cetanā (volition) in dependent origination.

33238.meaning_1: Second Discourse on Intention; Second Discourse on Volition
33238.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
A sutta in SN 12, the second discourse in a group dealing with cetanā (intention/volition) as a key factor in the arising of kamma and dependent origination.

29462.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
This is the title of SN12.40, the third sutta in the Nidānasaṃyutta (Connected Discourses on Causation) section on volition (cetanā). The sutta explains how volition is a condition for verbal, bodily, and mental actions.

24674.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
Refers to the fifth section of the Saṃyutta Nikāya, the "Connected Discourses with Householders," as indicated by the contextual sentence sn12.50:5.3: "gahapativaggo pañcamo" (The householder group is fifth).

39916.meaning_1: Discourse on the Five Fears; Sutta on the Five Dangers
39916.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence shows this is the title of a sutta in the Nidānasaṃyutta (Saṃyutta Nikāya 12). The compound breaks down to "pañca" (five) + "verabhaya" (fear/danger) + "sutta" (discourse).

33295.meaning_1: Second Discourse on the Five Fearful Dangers
33295.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The word appears in the nidaasaṃyutta of the Saṃyutta Nikāya as the title of a sutta. The context suggests it is a compound of dutiya (second), pañca (five), verabhaya (danger, fear), and sutta (discourse).

32959.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The compound is a kammadhāraya, meaning "the discourse concerning suffering." The contextual sentence lists it as a sutta within the Nidānasaṃyutta (Connected Discourses on Causation) of the Saṃyutta Nikāya.

28913.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In SN12.45, this appears as a title: "nidānasaṃyuttaṃ, ñātikasuttaṃ". It is part of the Nidānasaṃyutta of the Saṃyutta Nikāya, specifically the 12th chapter. The compound follows a kammadhāraya pattern (adjective + noun), where ñātika modifies sutta (discourse).

40863.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence sn12.45:1.3, "paṭisallāno" is used as a masculine singular adjective modifying the Buddha (bhagavā), meaning "in private retreat" or "in solitude." This aligns with the meaning "alone; secluded; in solitude." The form is the masculine nominative singular of the adjective, derived from the verb paṭisallīyati. The related neuter noun paṭisallāna (entry 40862) refers to the state or place of seclusion, while this adjectival form describes the person who is in that state.
40863.sutta_1: atha kho bhagavā rahogato paṭisallāno imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ abhāsi:
40863.example_1: Then while the Buddha was in private retreat he spoke this exposition of the teaching:

16206.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence 'bhagavato upassuti ṭhito hoti' (was standing listening in on the Buddha), the word functions as an abstract noun describing the act of listening in, not the person listening.
16206.sutta_1: tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu bhagavato upassuti ṭhito hoti.
16206.example_1: Now at that time a certain monk was standing listening in on the Buddha.

1513.meaning_1: a certain brāhmaṇa’s discourse; a sutta of a certain brāhmaṇa
1513.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence shows this is the title of a sutta in the Nidānasaṃyutta (SN 12.46). The compound describes a discourse (*sutta*) belonging to a specific (*aññatara*) brāhmaṇa. The standard Sanskrit reconstruction *sūkta* (well-spoken) is less likely here than *sūtra* (thread, discourse), aligning with the Pāḷi *sutta*.

28173.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
This is a proper name of a sutta found in SN 12.47. It refers to a discourse given to the brahmin Jāṇussoṇi.

58921.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence, it is used as a philosophical extreme ("this is one extreme") meaning "all exists". The construction shows sandhi where final -ṃ in sabbaṃ assimilates to -m before a vowel-initial word.

56048.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence identifies this as the name of a sutta in the Nidānasaṃyutta (SN 12.48). It refers to a discourse concerning "lokāyatika" (worldly or speculative views), likely the "six speculative views" in the first chapter of the Nidānasaṃyutta.

9024.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence shows this as the title of a sutta (SN12.49) within the Nidānasaṃyutta. It is a compound of ariyasāvaka (noble disciple) and sutta (discourse).

21933.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
An interrogative compound from kis(s)a (genitive sg. of kim) + uppāda, used in the dependent origination formula to ask "due to the arising of what does what arise?"
21933.sutta_1: kismiṃ sati kiṃ hoti, kissuppādā kiṃ uppajjati?
21933.example_1: ‘When what exists, what is? Due to the arising of what, what arises?

33144.meaning_1: the second discourse on the noble disciple
33144.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
This is the title of a sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN 12.50). The contextual sentence shows it is part of the Nidānasaṃyutta (Connected Discourses on Causation). The compound likely refers to the second discourse (dutiya) focused on a noble disciple (ariyasāvaka).

39915.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
From sn12.50:6.1: "dve pañcaverabhayā vuttā". The context suggests "five hatreds" (pañcavera) are mentioned along with two fears (dve bhayā). The compound appears to refer to five types of animosity or enmity.

32973.meaning_1: chapter of suffering; section on suffering (in the Saṃyutta Nikāya)
32973.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence 'dukkhavaggo chaṭṭho.' indicates 'The sixth chapter on suffering.' This is a standard compound referring to the chapters (vaggas) of the Saṃyutta Nikāya, specifically the Dukkha-saṃyutta (SN 12) or similar sections. The form 'dukkhavaggo' is the nominative singular masculine, fitting the 'a masc' pattern.

44301.meaning_1: discourse on investigation; discourse on scrutiny
44301.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The sutta belongs to the Nidānasaṃyutta (Saṃyutta Nikāya 12) and is numbered as SN 12.51. The term refers to a discourse specifically focused on the act of investigation or scrutiny (parivīmaṃsa) into the nature of dependent origination.

16338.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
Contextual sentence indicates this is the title of a sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN12.52). The compound is a kammadhāraya where upādāna (clinging) qualifies sutta (discourse).

10534.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The headword refers to a sutta where ignorance (avijjā) is presented as a fundamental condition (paccaya) for the arising of phenomena. In the context of SN12.35, it is part of the Nidāna Saṃyutta, which explores dependent origination.

28247.meaning_1: suitable for leading to the end of birth; fitting practice for cessation
28247.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence (SN 12.51) uses the feminine form jātinirodhasāruppagāminī modifying paṭipadā (practice). The compound describes a path (paṭipadā) that is suitable (sāruppa) for leading to (gāminī) the cessation (nirodha) of birth (jāti).
28247.sutta_1: so jātiñca pajānāti, jātisamudayañca pajānāti, jātinirodhañca pajānāti, yā ca jātinirodhasāruppagāminī paṭipadā tañca pajānāti, tathā paṭipanno ca hoti anudhammacārī;
28247.example_1: They understand rebirth, its origin, its cessation, and the fitting practice for its cessation. And they practice in line with that path.
